I have shot rifles and shotguns, but this Reply isn't about me. It's about professionals:

Although Gerald Ford was President for only a couple of years, 2 different people are known to have tried to kill him. He was always accompanied by Secret Service agents; the agents were not only armed but were routinely tested for their marksmanship. This was, after all, barely a dozen years after our 4th Presidential assassination.

So what did the agents do when a would-be assassin pointed a firearm at Ford -- and pulled the trigger? They wrestled the miscreant to the ground. The phrase "wrestled [someone/something] to the ground" became a running joke during Chevy Chase's year on "Saturday Night [Live]".

Fast-forward a handful of years. President Reagan exits the Hilton in a crowd of Secret Service agents, DC police, and other security people. The Secret Service men were certainly armed. Others may have been armed as well.

John Hinckley fired into the crowd; the Press Secretary was felled and the President himself was hit by a richocheting fragment. The security people were incredibly close to Hinckley. Did they draw and fire? Of course not. They used bodily force to subdue him on the pavement.

Think of recent history. A crazy man pulls out a gun on a train in France. Two US servicemen on leave, joined by a friend, are in the train car. How do they save all the other passengers? They use bodily force to subdue the nut.

Your fantasies of killing shooters are just that, .50 cal.

where do all these minibuses park?

They do not park. See my recommendation above.

There are different ways of looking at this recommendation, but the most basic is to regard it as the New York City's "omnibus peak shaving" concept. The vans would serve peak shaving purposes, not only with helping serve the peak loads in the City's center during normal business hours, but would also serve the peak commuting loads from and to the City's center before and after normal business hours.

What makes it work in both cases is the use the smaller peak shaving units--vans--rather than the larger regular buses. This van peak shaving capability would be completely under the control of and integrated with the City's intra and commuter bus systems. The routes and operations would be franchises of the City's bus system.

This is actually a really great idea. An informal Uber/Lyft. I like it! Emeryville and Oakland, California had a casual pickup - unregulated by anything more than word of mouth and habit, absolutely free to those waiting in line to be picked up, and YEARS before Uber/Lyft, so that East Bay commuters could get to SF through the carpool lane on the Bay Bridge when they weren't in convenient BART stop spots. So, this kind of stuff works!

Query though how this particular transit thoroughfare would work, given that the idea is this person would be driving through and returning to his/her own low-income neighborhood, and yet could afford a 16-passenger van? That vehicle, insurance (required for commercial purposes), and maintenance would be more than this driver normally signs up for or could maybe afford. A subsidy would be good, but that might ruin the democratic spirit. Definitely food for thought, though. I like we're you're going!

Congestion pricing to make traffic flow freely at all hours would be a huge step in the right direction.  With free flowing traffic, places in the suburbs all of a sudden become "closer" to midtown by bus than some parts of Manhattan are now.  So overnight you might double the number of housing units within 30 minutes of midtown jobs.  The next thing would be to allow commuters to drive licensed 16 passenger minibuses on specific routes in poorly served areas for a $3 fare.  The labor, fuel and vehicle cost is near zero as this person was going to commute in anyway.  When he goes home at 5:30, he also picks up people on the route so he's always full.  A middle class office worker might get an extra $80 per day on the roundtrip for the same commute he would be doing anyway. Also minibus is the fastest and most comfortable way to commute. You don't have 20 people getting on and off at every stop.  The problem with public transit is that it's full on the way in to Manhattan at 8am but empty when it goes back out at 9 and still empty (or infrequent) for the rest of the day until 5.   So fuel economy is much lower than you would expect and labor cost much higher.  Sadly labor unions would nix such a plan.  Other countries have this

In other words, when I have to get my car serviced something of it renewed from the DMV, it doesn't come cheap and some of it has increased in the last decade as well.  Overall, I feel that a form of transit should be paid more proportionally to those that are using such a form the most, not the least.

Here's the why I see it for those who take sides depending where they stand on the political spectrum.

Support and conservative: Believes that the market can be trusted to charge motorists when using the roads.
Support and liberal: Believes that road pricing will be good for the environment as well as reducing traffic on roads.
Oppose and conservative: Believes that the market can't be trusted especially in charging motorists to using the roads.
Oppose and liberal: Believes that any form of road pricing is viewed as a regressive tax to lower classes that are being forced to drive when not having any other choices.
